title: ICE says an immigrant who died in a sprawling Texas detention facility killed himself
summary:
EL PASO, Texas (AP) — An immigrant from Nicaragua was found dead at a Texas immigration detention facility last week, federal officials said.
Victor Manuel Diaz appears to have killed himself Wednesday at the sprawling tent complex at the U.S. Army's Fort Bill base in El Paso, Immigration and Customs Enforcement said in a statement.
It's the same facility where ICE said another detainee died earlier this month as staff members tried to keep him from killing himself.
Diaz was swept up on Jan. 6 in the federal crackdown on immigration in Minnesota and sent to Texas, ICE said.
The detainee said at least one of the guards squeezed an arm around Lunas Campos' neck.

title: Trump's ICE force is sweeping America. Billions in his tax and spending cuts bill are paying for it
summary:
Swelling ranks of ICE officers, to 22,000, in an expanding national force bigger than most police departments in America.
“Public sentiment is everything," said Rep. Nydia M. Velázquez, D-N.Y., at a press conference at the Capitol with lawmakers supporting legislation to impeach Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem.
House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., has warned Democrats that this is "no time to be playing games” by stirring up the opposition to immigration enforcement officers in Minneapolis and other places.
Noem has said the immigration enforcement officers are acting lawfully.
The legislation essentially doubled annual Homeland Security funding, adding $170 billion to be used over four years.

title: I'm an immigration lawyer in Minneapolis. People are scared — here's what employers and employees should know about their rights.
summary:
There's a huge concentration of ICE enforcement right now in Minnesota, specifically here in the Twin Cities.
Loan Huynh, an immigration attorney in Minneapolis, said that employees are scared due to ICE actions in the area, while employers are in a difficult position.
Or if you get a call from one of your employees who says, 'I'm too scared to walk out of my car here.
Individuals have constitutional rights, and don't need to succumb to threatsWe're seeing situations where an individual will say, "I don't want to speak with you," or, "I have counsel.
They have constitutional rights that, just because they are being threatened by an individual, don't mean that they have to succumb to those threats or requests.

title: 'Sign of the times': NY asylum-seekers arrested at routine immigration appointments
summary:
Rafael Andres Rubio Bohorquez, a data analyst, was taken into custody Jan. 12, when he appeared for a scheduled asylum interview with U.S.
Citizenship and Immigration Services, the agency that “oversees lawful immigration to the United States,” according to a lawsuit petitioning for his release.
But instead of sitting for the interview, he was arrested by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers and whisked into detention, court records show.
One of her clients was detained at the New York asylum office in October.
In the New York City area, 58% percent of the immigrants arrested by ICE under Trump through mid-October had no criminal history.

title: ICE detainee dies of 'presumed suicide' at Texas detention facility, agency says
summary:
The man was being held in a tent complex at the U.S. Army's Fort Bliss base.
This Aug. 7, 2025, satellite image shows construction of large white tents for a new immigrant detention center at Fort Bliss, a U.S. Army base outside El Paso, Texas.
This Aug. 7, 2025, satellite image shows construction of large white tents for a new immigrant detention center at Fort Bliss, a U.S. Army base outside El Paso, Texas.
Victor Manuel Diaz, 36, of Nicaragua, died of a "presumed suicide" on Jan. 14 at Camp East Montana, a sprawling tent complex at the U.S. Army's Fort Bliss base in El Paso, ICE said Sunday.
He was pronounced dead following life-saving measures by on-site medical staff and El Paso emergency medical services personnel, according to ICE.

title: Lawyers allege Dept. of Homeland Security is denying legal counsel to Minnesota detainees
summary:
Detainees are being held at the Whipple Federal Building in Minneapolis.
“ICE agents were physically restricting me from seeing them,” said one immigration attorney, who asked not to be identified.
REUTERS/Leah Millis Leah Millis/ReutersThe Department of Homeland Security denied that any constitutional violations are taking place at the Whipple Federal Building.
The Whipple building has been a primary facility where people detained during DHS' “Operation Metro Surge” are being temporarily held.
The immigration attorney also said access to an attorney by phone is different from access to an attorney in person.

title: From a refugee family to Nobel Laureate: Omar Yaghi’s story
summary:
Nobel laureate Omar Yaghi on how humble beginnings fueled breakthrough science against the climate crisis.
Nobel Laureate Dr. Omar Yaghi joins The Take after winning the 2025 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), materials that can capture carbon and store hydrogen.
Born to a Palestinian refugee family in Amman, Yaghi tells the story of how hardship shaped his imagination, from getting fresh water only once a week to inventing systems that pull water from desert air.
In this episode:Dr. Omar Yaghi, Nobel Laureate in Chemistry, Professor at University of California, Berkeley and Atoco FounderEpisode credits:This episode was produced by Chloe K. Li and Melanie Marich with Phillip Lanos, Spencer Cline, Tamara Khandaker, Kylene Kiang, Sarí el-Khalili and our host, Malika Bilal.
The Take production team is Marcos Bartolomé, Sonia Bhagat, Spencer Cline, Sarí el-Khalili, Tamara Khandaker, Kylene Kiang, Phillip Lanos, Chloe K. Li, Melanie Marich, and Noor Wazwaz.

title: US Justice Department probes Minnesota officials amid migration raids
summary:
The investigation will look into whether Minnesota officials blocked federal immigration agents from carrying out their duties.
The DOJ probe will review whether Minnesota state officials conspired to obstruct justice by preventing federal immigration officers from carrying out their duties, US broadcaster CBS News reported late on Tuesday.
Governor Walz confirmed the DOJ investigation in a statement on Tuesday, describing the move as “political theatre”.
“This Justice Department investigation, sparked by calls for accountability in the face of violence, chaos and the killing of Renee Good, does not seek justice.
Minneapolis Mayor Frey described the DOJ investigation as an attempt to intimidate state officials.

title: Judge refuses to block new DHS policy limiting Congress members' access to ICE facilities
summary:
WASHINGTON (AP) — A federal judge refused Monday to temporarily block the Trump administration from enforcing a new policy requiring a week's notice before members of Congress can visit immigration detention facilities.
Rather, she said, plaintiffs' attorneys representing several Democratic members of Congress used the wrong "procedural vehicle" to challenge it.
She ruled Dec. 17 that it is likely illegal for ICE to demand a week’s notice from members of Congress seeking to visit and observe conditions in ICE facilities.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement AdvertisementA law bars DHS from using appropriated general funds to prevent members of Congress from entering DHS facilities for oversight purposes.
Government attorneys have said it’s merely speculative for the legislators to be concerned that conditions in ICE facilities change over the course of a week.
